text: Union Station, that gorgeous fifty-year-old monument to A Deco/California Mission architecture. Still beautiful. St grand. A sign at one of the departure/arrival gates in the main  concourse-says the "San Diegan", number 2 64, is due at 1 Set above the gates, a big clock - six feet in diameter.
We see the big hand slam into "7". A loudspeaker - you can just about understand this guy.
Amtrack 2 64, the San Diegan, from  San Diego, Del Mar...
The "San Diegan" pulls into the terminal and comes to a s grinding stop.
...San Clemente, San Juan Capistrano,  and Irvine is now arriving at Gate  Nine.
Doors are opened. Steps set down. Passengers pour out.
Amtrack 264 will be departing in  fifteen minutes from Gate Nine for  Oxnard, Ventura...
A MAN and A WOMAN stand with a view of the arrival doors. He's a blue-collar tough guy, dressed for church. She's h beefy counterpart.
...Santa Barbara, Lompoc...
THE GUY (MR. SMITH) checks his watch.
...Santa Maria, San Luis Obispo...
Then he looks up to the big clock. 12:07. The minute hand slams into the "8".
...and points north.
He resets his watch as DISEMBARKING PASSENGERS pour out o the gate. PEOPLE run forward with kisses and hugs.
Look sharp.
They stand like a couple of rocks, their eyes scanning th crowd.
That one.
Nah.  Hates his wife.
They're talking about a couple in their forties.  She  motormouths her way across the terminal and the husband  follows with the suitcases. WHOOSH! A couple of TEENAGE BOYS on rollerblades zip by.
I hate rollerblades.
The train.. A PRETTY SIX-YEAR-OLD GIRL (LYNN) , who is ho a stuffed animal almost as large as she is, climbs down t steps. She reaches the platform, looks around. From withi the train:
Lynn!  Lynn!!
GENE WATSON, thirtyish, a regular Joe in appearance and  inclination, appears above, carrying a couple small suitc He takes a relieved breath when he sees  her.
Lynn, don't walk ahead of me, OK?
As he comes down the steps:
I'm serious, honey. Don't get out of  my sight, all right? I want you to  stay right by me. Will you do that  for me?
Nods solemnly. GENE reaches the  platform and gives out an exaggerated  sigh.
We made it.
LYNN nods back.
We made it.

WHOOSH! A SECURITY GUARD approaches the two ROLLERBLADING TEENS. They circle him, toss off a few taunts and roll aw laughing. MR. SMITH and MS. JONES continue trolling the PASSENGERS they come through the gate.
Skate-boarders I don't mind, even  though they dress like fuckin' idiots,  but when I see some pin-head on  rollerblades, I get the definite  urge to grease the grill of my car  with 'em.
Keep your eyes peeled.
What about them?
Too old.
They're talking about a COUPLE IN THEIR SIXTIES, warmly  greeting each other.
Him!
If you ever had an idea it would die  of malnutrition. First those blue  hairs then some Spic.  Leave this to  me. I know people. It's my job. I'm  a people person.
MR. SMITH laughs at his joke.
What the fuck are you looking for?
MR. SMITH has spotted someone.
I'm looking for them.
Where?
Right there.
He starts walking towards the exit gate.
GENE has emerged with LYNN. They pause there, getting the bearings. Next to them, a YOUNG COUPLE is kissing. They c keep their hands off each other.
I gotta make a phone call, Lynn. Do  you see a phone?
LYNN has seen the YOUNG COUPLE. She secretly points to th covers her mouth, and does a "tee, hee, hee" number. GENE laughs.
Come on, you.
They start walking across the concourse, towards MR. SMIT and MS. JONES.
(to LYNN) Haven't you ever seen anybody kiss  like that?
On TV.
You never saw your Mom and me kiss  like that?

LYNN suddenly gets very sad. She looks at the ground, slo down. GENE notices. He stops, crouches down to her level. MR. SMITH and MS. JONES, nearing them, split apart, move  around them, and keep going.
(to LYNN) Hey, it's OK to talk about her. You  can talk about her all you want. You  know that, don't you?
LYNN nods.
So, come on. You never saw us kiss  like that?
No way.
How did you see us kiss?
LYNN gives her own hand a little peck of a kiss.
That's it? That little peck of a  kiss? Oh, brother, you missed some  kisses.
LYNN laughs and throws herself on her dad. He holds her t him, looks to the sky for help.. He finds himself staring the big clock. 12:10.
Ooh, I'm gonna be late. I gotta call.

MR. SMITH and MS. JONES are making a beeline for their ta the YOUNG KISSING COUPLE. WHOOSH! The-ROLLERBLADING TEENS almost collide with them. MS. JONES wants to do something about it, but MR. SMITH p her along. They have a mission to complete. They close in the couple.
Look at 'em. He'd do anything for  her.-
Young love.

The couple are murmuring sweet talk between kisses. The w themselves are unclear until MR. SMITH and MS. JONES are  only a few feet away. French. They are speaking French. M SMITH makes an instant one-eighty turn. MS. JONES follows
(sotto voce) Foreigners! Fuck!
Frogs. They copy our blue jeans and  when we need their help in Kuwait,  where the fuck are they?
MR. SMITH looks at the partner he's been saddled with.
GENE has found a pay phone. He keeps an eye on LYNN who h wandered a few yards away.
Hello, is Mr. Conners there? I have  an interview with him at twelve- thirty. Hi, Mr. Conners, this is  Gene Watson. Sorry to call you at  the last minute like this but...  Hey, hey!
He reacts to the ROLLERBLADING TEENS who swoop past LYNN, one on each side, too close for a father's comfort.
Watch that! Lynn, come here!
She does. He keeps an eye on the TEENS, who, having found victim, are circling around, passing MR. SMITH and .MS. J MR. SMITH has noticed GENE. GENE at the phone.
Sorry. There's some crazy kids on  skates. Listen, the train just got  in, I'm afraid I'm going to be a few  minutes late.

The TEENS make their pass, flip him the bird, engage in o objectionable behavior, begin to circle again. MR. SMITH  watches GENE watch the TEENS, then notice a sturdy, sand- filled ashtray next to him.
Great. OK, I'll get there as soon as  I can. Bye, now.
He hangs up. Keeping one eye on the circling TEENS.
(to LYNN) Ready?
Nods.
Let' s do it.

He picks up a suit-case and accidently-on-purpose uses it knock over the ashtray, just as the TEENS approach. The  ashtray spills its Load of sand into their path. When the hit it, their skates stop, they don't. They sprawl, doing nasty things to knees and wrists.
Whoops.
He stands over them with LYNN.
Now, see, this is why you should  always wear a helmet and knee pads.  You never know when you're going to  fall down and go boom. Right?
Right.
Perfect.
He starts forward.
(not so sure) Perfect.
She follows. They intercept GENE. MR. SMITH flashes a bad
Could I see some identification,  sir?
What?
(ditto with the badge) I.D. Could we see some?
Uh, sure. What's, what's the problem?  Will a driver's license do?
That'll do just fine.
GENE pulls out his wallet, surprised and confused. MR. SM looks at it.
Is this about those kids? Look, I'm  sorry about that. But they darn  near...
You're from Santa Maria, Mr. Watson?
Yes.
Where's that?
Near Lompoc, north. What's...
Come with us, sir.
I'd like to know what...
Don't cause a ruckus, sir.
He pulls open his coat, putting his hands on his hips, no so coincidentally revealing the butt of a holstered gun.
You don't want to cause a ruckus,  with the little girl and all.
Come with me, honey.
MS. JONES swoops LYNN up and heads for the station entran
Hey! I'll take the girl. I'll take  the girl!
Don't worry. She's good with kids.
GENE hurries after MS. JONES. MR. SMITH grabs up the  suitcases.
MS. JONES nears a souvenir stand. The OWNER is looking th other way. Without breaking stride, MS. JONES reaches out snatches a child's coloring book and crayons.
You stole that.
No, I didn't. I confiscated it.  There's a difference.
And they're out the door, GENE hurrying after. The big ha on the big clock moves. 12:12.
MS. JONES heads for-a van with smoked windows. She gets i with LYNN. GENE stops a few feet away.
What is going on?
MR. SMITH prods him in the ribs.
Into the van, Mr. Watson. Front seat.
GENE looks desperately around for help. There is none. He lets MR. SMITH push him toward the van.
LYNN and MS. JONES are in the back.
Let's get your seatbelt on. Always  gotta wear your seatbelt, isn't that  right?
LYNN resists.
I want my daddy.
GENE climbs into the front passenger seat.
There's your daddy. See? We're your  daddy's friends.
MR. SMITH climbs into the driver's seat.
That's right. The policeman is your  friend. Isn't that right, Daddy?
GENE looks down. MR.. SMITH has pulled his gun. He points casually so it's aiming through the seat in the general  direction of the little girl.
Daddy?
Yes. It's OK, Lynn. These are our  friends.
Hey, would you look at this crazy  car? Everybody has their own radio.  What do you think of that?
Everybody does?
Yep. And you can listen to it without  anybody else listening. Let's try it  out.
She puts some ear phones on her. She holds up the plug-in end.
This is what they call the jack. Hi,  Jack!
Laughs.
It goes in that little hole.
Let me do it.
She plugs the jack in. MS. JONES turns on the radio. LYNN gets a big smile on her face.
(loudly) It's loud!
She goes to work, playing with the radio, changing statio etc., oblivious to all else.
Removes a Pro Label Machine from  under the seat. She begins to type  in several characters.
Let's get down to business.
Who are you? You're not the police.
Brilliant.
MS JONES presses PRINT on the Labeller. A strip of plasti emerges that she begins to apply to a Name Tag.  He looks back to her. MR. SMITH whacks him on the knee with the gu It hurts.
Pay attention, Mr. Watson. Pay  attention and your daughter won't be  hurt.
You wouldn't...
Try us.
He looks back. She is caressing LYNN's hair.
Get your hands off her.
He makes a move. MR. SMITH whacks his knee again, harder.
Mr. Watson, you're not paying  attention. Your daughter's life  depends on you. Do you understand  that?
GENE looks from MR. SMITH to MS. JONES and back. He's hav a hard time focussing. She slips the NameTag into a manila envelope beside her M SMITH Do you understand?
Yes, yes, I understand.
Good.
He takes the manila envelope from MS JONES, tosses it in  GENE'S lap.
This is for you. In it there is a  picture of a woman and an itinerary.  It is her itinerary. She is presently -  are you listening, Mr. Watson?
Yes, I'm listening.
She is presently at the Bonaventure  Hotel. That's right near here.
He gestures. GENE looks. The glassy Bonaventure Hotel is  glimpsed surrounded by taller, newer high-rises.
When you leave this van you will get  yourself a cab and take it to the  Bonaventure Hotel. Then you will  take this.
MR. SMITH holds up his hand, snaps his fingers. From the  back, MS. JONES hands him a cloth-wrapped bundle. He puts in GENE's hand, shows him what it is: a gun.
...and you will kill the woman whose  picture is in there. Not just shoot  her, mind,! kill her. I'd recommend  you empty the gun into her. Close  up. Got all that?
It takes a moment for it all to sink into GENE'S brain.
You're out of your mind.
What's your point?
I will do no such thing.
Yes, you will, Mr. Watson.
A "snap!" from the back seat. GENE looks. MS. JONES has b a carrot stick. She breaks another.
Don't worry. We'll take good care of  the kid.
She gives half the carrot stick to LYNN, pops the other h in her mouth and grinds it to pulp. MR. SMITH is checking his watch.
It is now 12:16. If the woman in the  picture is alive at 1:30... (holds up a walkie- talkie) ...I call my partner, your daughter  is dead.
He looks in the rear-view mirror to MS. JONES.
And what happens if I don't call  you?
I kill her anyway.
Did you hear that, Mr. Watson? Do  you understand?
He taps the manila envelope.
The woman in the picture...
He indicates the back seat with his head.
...or your daughter.
GENE looks at his daughter.
Oh, my God...
MR. SMITH reaches over, puts the gun and manila envelope  into GENE'S pockets.
God can't help her, Mr. Watson. Only  you can help her.
Only you.
You're wasting time.
He reaches across GENE, opens the door and pushes him out then follows him. LYNN takes off the ear-phones, tries to undo her seatbelt.
Where is my daddy going?
MS. JONES wraps a big arm around her.
He's going to help the police. Your  daddy is going to be a hero.
My daddy is going to be a hero? Like  Power Rangers?
Just like Power Rangers.
MR. SMITH activates the walkie-talkie, speaks into it.
Let's test this thing. You on?
He holds it up for GENE to hear.
(filtered) Reading you.
MR. SMITH still has GENE'S wallet. He opens it, pulls out some cash, puts it in GENE's breast pocket.
You'11 need some cash. (re: the wallet) I'll hang onto this for the time  being. Oh, and...
He grabs one of GENE's hands.
You'll need these.
He dumps six bullet's into GENE's palm from a cloth Chiva Regal bag.
Get moving, Mr. Watson. Time's a  wastin'.
GENE just stands there, transfixed by the bullets in his  hand. MR. SMITH reaches out, turns him around and gives h a shove away from the van and into the midst of...

...a LARGE CROWD OF TOURISTS, that have just exited an  arriving mini-bus. GENE is caught up in the crowd and car along like a leaf in a stream. Amid the chattering CROWD, GENE is pushed along as if in trance. He touches the pocket with the gun. He looks at t Bullets in his hand, then at the people around him. It's  like a splash of cold water. He quickly pockets the bulle turns and pushes against the tide of tourists. They resis him, pushing him along until he breaks free and can see.. The van is gone!

He stands there, a lost man. Fear sweeps over him. He loo desperately around. He is within himself, oblivious to hi surroundings, his mind racing, his face a tangle of emoti He is a man alone in a crowd. He takes a step. A LITTLE LATINO GIRL, chased by HER BROTHER, runs into GE legs. He instinctively grabs her before she can fall, fin himself, crouched down, holding her by the arms. His hear plunges - she isn't Lynn. His intensity scares her.
Mama!

She pulls away, flees to HER MOTHER, who hoists her up,  reprimanding her in Spanish. GENE stays crouched, watchin the LITTLE GIRL staring at him over HER MOTHER'S shoulder Until a COP crosses his line of sight. A LOS ANGELES TRAN POLICEMAN, foot-patrolling the station. It's like a gift from above. Relief floods GENE's face. H is saved. He stands, hurries toward the COP, each step mo confident. Then, just beyond the COP, MR. SMITH casually slides into view, pointedly holding the walkie-talkie. GENE walks rig past the COP heading towards a cab stand. MR. SMITH falls behind him speaking in his ear.
You talk to a cop, you even look at  a cop too long and your daughter is  dead. (into walkie-talkie) Do it.
(filtered) Go ahead, sugar Die.
(filtered) Lynn calling Daddy. Lynn calling  Daddy. Come in, Daddy.
GENE grabs at the walkie-talkie like a drowning man.
Lynn!
(filtered) I can hear you good. Can you hear  me?
Yes. Yes, I can hear you.
That's enough.
(filtered) 'Daddy has to go now.
(filtered) He has to say "over and out". Daddy,  you have to say "over and out".
Over and out.
MR. SMITH clicks off the walkie-talkie.
Look at your watch. Look at it! At  one-thirty your little girl is dead.  Say it with me. At one-thirty my  little girl is dead. Say it. Say it!
(softly) At one thirty my little girl is dead.
Unless you do what you're told. Go  do it!
He pushes GENE on, toward a cab.
And don't forget I'll be watching  you.
GENE looks back at him, full of impotent rage. MR. SMITH  raises the walkie-talkie. GENE reaches the first cab at t stand.
The CABBIE, talking to ANOTHER DRIVER, throws away his  cigarette, ambles over to the Driverside-of the cab.
Where to, sir?
The Bonaventure. The Bonaventure  Hotel. Do you know where that is?
The CABBIE is disappointed, but he nods and GENE gets int the cab.
The CABBIE gets in and they take off. GENE stares at the  manila envelope in his hand. He starts to open it, is sto by:
Amtrack?
What?
You just come in on Amtrack?
Uh, yes..
Business or pleasure?
Business.
Where'd you come from?
San Diego.

Oh, San Diego? I've thought about  moving to San Diego.  It's hard to  make a living in this town. These  short hops.  Can't make a dime on  'em. To LAX, Pasadena, then I can  make a buck. These little hops cost  me money.
Sorry.
'S okay. What do you think?
Huh?
Better in San Diego? More opportunity  there? What?
I really don't know. I don't live  there. I was just visiting...a grave.
Aw, too bad.
They lapse into silence. GENE starts to open the envelope again.
Somebody close?
What?
The grave. Somebody close?
Wife. Ex-wife. Almost ex. We were  separated. She was thinking about a  divorce.
GENE notices the dashboard clock - 12:22 GENE leans forward.
Look...I've... I've got a problem. A  big problem...
Oh, yeah?
He hits the horn and swerves to the left.
Jesus! Watch it, buddy!
GENE looks out his window and finds himself staring at MR SMITH, staring back at him, driving the van, next to him. throws himself back in the seat.
The cab pulls into the drive front of the Bonaventure Hot and stops.
I'd love to hear about your problem,  but the ride's over. Three-fifty.
GENE looks out the back window, watches the van pulls up the curb on the other side of the street.
Three-fifty. I hope your problem  doesn't have anything to do with my  three-fifty.
GENE looks back at the CABBIE, waiting for his fare.
Right. Right.

GENE digs through his pockets and comes up with one of hi business cards. He hurriedly writes on it: "HELP. VAN KID CHILD." He wraps a five around it, pushes it into the CAB hand, gives him a meaningful look and gets out of the cab
GENE stops a few yards from the cab, watching the CABBIE.
The CABBIE finds the secreted card, but looks at the wron side.
What do I want with an accountant?
A DOORMAN leans down at the window.
I got one for the airport. You free?
You bet.
The DOORMAN plants a PASSENGER in the cab. As he pulls aw the CABBIE again glances at the business card, crumples i up.

GENE watches the cab leave. As it exits, the CABBIE's arm snakes out and tosses the card in the trash. GENE knows w it is. He looks around. VALETS, BELLMEN, ARRIVALS and DEPARTEES, cars coming and  going. No one pays particular attention to him. GENE looks at the van across the street. MR. SMITH gets o and walks across the street towards him. The van drives a GENE watches the van disappear around the corner, despera hanging onto the last glimpse of it. MR. SMITH takes the walkie-talkie out of his pocket. GENE goes into the hotel.
GENE enters. It's like another world. A busy, humming, ai conditioned planet. PEOPLE hustle around the restaurants, waterfalls - a definite ant farm ambiance.
Suddenly we have cut to a VIDEO IMAGE of Gene looking aro this Hotel, complete with scrolling TIME AND DATE. Shot b someone high above.
GENE is bumped and buffeted about by the bustling crowd. breaks free to a clear spot, looks up and freezes. Then h starts tracking all around him, seeing...something.
Oh, my God. Oh, no.

He desperately fumbles in his pocket. Facing and above him, some WORKMEN ON LADDERS are securin huge, rolled up banner. GENE finds what he's looking for - the manila envelope. H rips it open. As he pulls out the photograph that is insi the WORKMEN let their banner unfurl. We do a simultaneous reveal. The woman in the photograph in the envelope is th same as depicted on the banner. Written across the bottom it in your best red, white, and blue: "RE-ELECT ELEANOR SAMARA GRANT GOVERNOR"
And an addendum:
Oh, shit.

It dawns on him. He looks around him again. This time we what he sees. Campaign posters and banners everywhere.  On some of them she is posed with a handsome man, several years her junior. These have the caption, "Governor Grant and husband Brendan".
Oh, sweet Jesus...

His eyes fall on MR. SMITH, standing inside the entrance, walkie-talkie in hand, watching him. GENE looks at a poster, at MR. SMITH, who smiles, nods an gives GENE a move of the head - "Get to it." GENE shoves the photograph away as if it could incriminat him, then slides out the itinerary. The itinerary says "California Educators' Association - 1 noon - Emerald Bay Room - Opening Address - Governor Elea Samara Grant". GENE checks his watch. 12:26. He looks around him at the confusion and spots a Bellboy, GUSTINO, who's cleaning out ashtrays.
Could you tell me where the Emerald  Bay Room is?
GUSTINO points up.
Third floor. Yellow stairwell. Follow  the signs.
GENE turns away without a word, starts to walk, then turn back.
Oh, thanks. Thanks a lot.
GUSTINO smiles.
No problem.
GENE mounts a set of stairs that will take him to the thi floor. MR. SMITH follows him as he climbs.
The whole lobby and entrance of the hotel are seen as Gen ascends. GENE forces himself not to look at MR. SMITH behind him. nerves are rising in anticipation of his destination.
GENE sees the arrow and sign for the Emerald Bay Room.  H walks that way. MR. SMITH follows.

GENE and MR. SMITH pass gift shops, snack bars. The walkw is crowded and GENE is going against the tide of REPORTER POLITICIANS, SUPPORTERS, and just a lot of PEOPLE WITH NA TAGS. GENE plows on through... ...and runs smack into BRENDAN GRANT.
(laughs) Whoops!
The two men reel back from each other. A SECURITY MAN,  earphones and gray suit, steps immediately between them.  BRENDAN GRANT is a charmingly smooth man.
Nice body check.

He continues on, talking to an ATTRACTIVE WCMAN COMPANION BRENDAN GRANT What the Governor really admires, Mrs. Went and Eleanor has said this to me on more than one occasion are pecple like you who take a personal tragedy and turn into a positive force. He slides a familiar hand around her waist.
You know my wife has a deeply personal  reason for going after repeat drunk  drivers. They are felons and they  should be treated as such. A drivers  license is a privilege, not a right.
And he is hustled away. Right past an election poster  featuring him and Governor Grant. Still stunned by the encounter, GENE turns back and watch the Governor's husband, but keeps walking.
It is emptying, that's where the crowd came from. GENE co in. A WOMAN is heading for the door with a centerpiece she's  just copped.
Excuse me, is the...thing over?
Yes. You didn't miss much. The  food...chicken again.
Eleanor Grant is gone?
Yes. Nice speech. But it's the same  at all these...

But GENE has turned away. The WOMAN gives him a face, gra another centerpiece and exits. A CLEAN-UP CREW is startin to go through the room. GENE leans against a wall, breath through a combination of relief and agony. MR. SMITH is suddenly next to him.
Check your itinerary. Move along.
GENE gets out the itinerary. "12:30 - 12:45 - Hors d'oeuv Buffet w/Friends of Eleanor Samara Grant - INVITATION ONL Bona Vista Lounge".
This says "invitation only".
Of course you're invited. You're a  big donor to the campaign. They love  you.

MR SMITH digs  into the manila envelope, comes out with a handful of security badges, name tags, invites. He plucks the name tag that MS JONES printed earlier. It has a red  ribbon signifying a Major Donor to the Campaign. He faste it to Gene's lapel.
This'11 get you in anywhere.  Red  Elevator. Thirty-fifth floor.
Where did you get these? Who are  you?
I'm the guy who's going to kill your  daughter if you don't get moving.

GENE approaches. He notices a flurry of movement, a small GROUP OF PEOPLE moving determinedly through the lobby. It GOVERNOR ELEANOR GRANT with a small entourage!  She is a  handsome woman in her fifties. The entourage consists of  KRISTA BROOKS, Eleanor's, late-twenties assistant, a few  assorted POLITICAL AIDES and a couple of PEOPLE WITH NAME TAGS. GENE is not sure what to do. The group reaches the  elevator. KRISTA pushes the button.
They-didn't hear a word I said. The  mike was too low on the podium.
How much did we pay for that room?
We didn't.
Somebody did.
KRISTA turns to an Aide.
A Have Nolin pre-check the PA systems.

The elevator doors open. They crowd in. The doors start t close. Gene looks around, where did Mr. Smith go? GENE springs forward, thrusts his hand between them. The  doors stop, then bounce open. GENE is startled, finding  himself face to face with a cold eyed bodyguard.
Excuse me, sir, this car is for the  Governor. You can take the next one.
Don't you dare, Franco. This is one  of our biggest supporters.
She smiles charmingly, offers her hand to GENE.
Eleanor Grant, gubernatorial  incumbent. That's a mouthful isn't-  it? I love saying that.
GENE steps aboard, shakes her hand.
The elevator begins to rise.
Whose idea was it to have a lunch  right after the brunch? I'm about to  bust as it is.
We'll just walk through, do a little  grip-and-grin, then get ready for  the press con.
We are on the third floor. The doors have closed and the elevator begins to rise.
Governor...
It comes out a little louder then he intended. He has tur his back to the door. Everyone looks at him. He's committ
I need your help.
What can I do for you Mr....Watson?
Its'...ah...about my daughter....
The elevator slows and stops on the next floor above.
We are on the fourth floor. Behind GENE, the doors open.
Room for one more?
GENE freezes.
I think we can accommodate you.
She offers her hand to MR. SMITH as he steps on board.
Eleanor Grant, gubernatorial  incumbent.
A pleasure to meet you, Governor.
The car begins to rise again. ELEANOR .GRANT turns back t GENE.
You were saying?  Your daughter....?
Yes?
Yes???
What to do now?
She ..ahh...wanted me to... be sure  to get your autograph.
Of course.  I wish everything were  that easy.
I've got the pen if you've got the  paper.
GENE looks at her. She smiles back.
How about that?
He looks at what she refers to: the manila envelope he ho the one MR. SMITH gave him.
Is that something precious?
No, that's,..that's fine
He gives it to ELEANOR GRANT. KRISTA hands over the pen.  GENE's eyes flick over to MR. SMITH who is staring at the envelope.
What's her name?
GENE looks at the Governor, only inches away, back to MR. SMITH, who raises his eyes, nods, his silent message curt do it! GENE pulls his eyes away.
Her name? Her name is Lynn.

ELEANOR GRANT writes the autograph. MR. SMITH'S eyes dril into him. GENE looks over. MR. SMITH raises a hand to his face, pretends to scratch an itch. His other hand taps hi wristwatch. GENE's hand slides toward his jacket pocket. Sweat beads on his forehead. He's barely aware of KRISTA  talking to him.
It's funny. I don't even keep a pad  of paper with me anymore, everything's  gone so electronic.
He gives her a quick, weak smile. His free hand wipes the sweat from his face.
If it wasn't for double A batteries  I'd be in big trouble.

He is slowly reaching into the pocket with the gun, but s when he notices MR. SMITH'S hand slide into his jacket, w his gun is. He looks at the other MR.
